conclusion: We need to determine the friction force acting on block A on the inclined plane using static equilibrium and given information.
In Figure A, block A is resting on an inclined plane with an angle θ = 37°.
In Figure B, block A is on an inclined plane with θ = 30°, and a smooth cylinder B with mass m is placed between A and the inclined plane.
When θ = 37°, the block A can just rest on the inclined plane, meaning the friction force is equal to the normal force (N) and the weight of the block (mg).
The tangent of θ is calculated as tan(37°) = sin(37°) / cos(37°) = 0.6 / 0.8 = 0.75.
The normal force (N) is calculated as N = mg * tan(37°) = 4m * 0.75 = 3m.
The weight of the block (mg) is calculated as mg = M * sin(37°) = 4m * 0.6 = 2.4m.
The friction force (f) is equal to the normal force (N), so f = N = 3m.
When θ = 30°, the tangent of θ is calculated as tan(30°) = sin(30°) / cos(30°) = 1/√3.
The friction force (f') when θ = 30° is calculated as f' = mg * tan(30°) = 4m * (1/√3) = 4m/√3.
The friction force (f) when θ = 30° is equal to the normal force (N), so f = N = 3m.
The friction force (f') when θ = 30° is recalculated as f' = mg * tan(30°) = 4m * (1/√3) = 4m/√3.
The final friction force of A on the slope is determined to be 2√3m.
